Gingerbread Waffles

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to the cozy world of gingerbread waffles, where the warm spices of ginger, cinnamon, and nutmeg come together to create a delightful breakfast treat that’s perfect for chilly mornings. Imagine biting into a fluffy, golden waffle infused with the rich flavors of molasses and brown sugar, reminiscent of your favorite holiday cookies. This recipe not only captures the essence of traditional gingerbread but also transforms it into a comforting, easy-to-make breakfast option that will impress your family and friends. Whether you’re hosting a festive brunch or simply treating yourself to a special morning meal, these gingerbread waffles are sure to bring warmth and joy to your table. With a simple ingredient list and straightforward instructions, you’ll be savoring these delicious treats in no time! So grab your waffle iron and let’s dive into creating these scrumptious gingerbread waffles that embody the spirit of the season!

Ingredients

all-purpose flour

All-purpose flour is versatile and can be substituted with whole wheat flour for a nuttier flavor, or gluten-free flour blends for a gluten-free option. To enhance flavor, consider adding a pinch of vanilla extract or a tablespoon of cocoa powder to the mix.

baking powder

Ensure your baking powder is fresh for optimal leavening. If you run out, you can substitute 1 teaspoon of baking powder with 1/4 teaspoon baking soda and 1/2 teaspoon of cream of tartar.

baking soda

Baking soda is crucial for helping the waffles rise. If you don't have baking soda, you can substitute it with baking powder, but you'll need to increase the amount slightly (about triple the amount of baking powder for the same effect).

ground ginger

Ground ginger adds warmth and spice. If you prefer a milder flavor, reduce the amount or substitute with fresh ginger (use about 1 tablespoon of freshly grated ginger).

ground cinnamon

Cinnamon is key for warmth in gingerbread recipes. You can enhance its flavor by toasting the ground cinnamon lightly in a dry pan before adding it to the mix.

ground nutmeg

Nutmeg adds a cozy flavor. Use freshly grated nutmeg if possible for a stronger flavor; half the amount of ground nutmeg can also work in a pinch.

salt

Salt enhances the sweetness of the waffles. You can use sea salt or kosher salt, but avoid table salt if possible, as it can be more potent.

brown sugar

Brown sugar adds moisture and depth to the flavor. You can substitute it with white sugar mixed with a bit of molasses (1 tablespoon of molasses for every cup of white sugar) if needed.

molasses

Molasses gives the waffles their characteristic gingerbread flavor. If you lack molasses, you can substitute with dark corn syrup or honey, but the flavor will be different.

milk

Milk adds richness to the batter. You can substitute with almond milk, oat milk, or any non-dairy milk for a lactose-free option. For a thicker batter, use buttermilk.

eggs

Eggs bind the ingredients and add moisture. If you're looking for an egg substitute, use 1/4 cup of unsweetened applesauce or 1/2 ripe banana per egg.

butter, melted

Melted butter adds richness and flavor. You can substitute with vegetable oil or coconut oil for a dairy-free version, but the flavor may differ.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Preheat the Waffle Iron

    Start by preheating your waffle iron according to the manufacturer's instructions. This ensures that your waffles will cook evenly and achieve that perfect golden brown color.

  • Step 2: Mix Dry Ingredients

    In a large bowl, whisk together 1 3/4 cups of all-purpose flour, 1 tablespoon of baking powder, 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda, 1 teaspoon of ground ginger, 1 teaspoon of ground cinnamon, 1/4 teaspoon of ground nutmeg, 1/2 teaspoon of salt, and 1/4 cup of brown sugar until well combined. Make sure there are no lumps in the mixture.

  • Step 3: Combine Wet Ingredients

    In another bowl, mix together 1/2 cup of molasses, 1 1/2 cups of milk, 2 eggs, and 1/2 cup of melted butter until smooth. This step is crucial for ensuring that the molasses is fully incorporated.

  • Step 4: Combine Wet and Dry Mixtures

    Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir gently until just combined. It's important not to overmix; a few lumps are okay. This helps keep your waffles fluffy.

  • Step 5: Prepare the Waffle Iron

    Lightly grease the waffle iron with cooking spray or a little oil to prevent sticking. Be generous but not excessive to ensure even cooking.

  • Step 6: Cook the Waffles

    Pour enough batter into the waffle iron to cover the surface. Close the waffle iron and cook according to the manufacturer's instructions, usually for about 5 minutes or until the waffles are golden brown and cooked through.

  • Step 7: Serve and Enjoy

    Carefully remove the waffles using a fork or tongs to avoid burning yourself. Serve warm with syrup, whipped cream, or fresh fruit. Enjoy your delicious gingerbread waffles!

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I measure flour properly?

To measure flour, use the spoon-and-level method: spoon flour into your measuring cup without packing it down, then level off the excess with a straight edge like a knife. This prevents using too much flour, which can make your waffles dense.

What can I substitute for molasses?

If you don't have molasses, you can substitute it with an equal amount of honey or maple syrup. Keep in mind that the flavor will be slightly different, but it will still add sweetness and moisture.

How do I know when my waffle iron is ready?

Most waffle irons have an indicator light that tells you when they're preheated. If yours doesn't, you can test it by sprinkling a few drops of water on the surface; if they sizzle and evaporate, the iron is ready.

Why should I not overmix the batter?

Overmixing can develop gluten in the flour, which makes waffles tough instead of light and fluffy. Mix just until the ingredients are combined, even if there are a few lumps.

What should I do if my waffles stick to the waffle iron?

To prevent sticking, make sure to grease the waffle iron well with cooking spray or oil before adding the batter. If they still stick, let them cook a little longer before trying to remove them.

Can I make the batter ahead of time?

Yes, you can prepare the batter the night before and store it in the refrigerator. Just give it a gentle stir before using, as it may thicken overnight.

How can I tell when my waffles are done cooking?

Waffles are ready when they are golden brown and crisp on the outside. If your waffle iron has a light, it will usually turn off or change color when the waffles are done.

What toppings can I add to my gingerbread waffles?

Gingerbread waffles pair wonderfully with maple syrup, whipped cream, fresh fruit like berries or bananas, or even a sprinkle of powdered sugar or nuts for added texture.

How do I clean my waffle iron?

To clean your waffle iron, unplug it and let it cool. Use a damp cloth or sponge to wipe down the surfaces. For stubborn bits of batter, you can use a soft brush or a plastic spatula. Avoid using metal utensils that can scratch the nonstick surface.

Can I freeze leftover waffles?

Yes! Let your waffles cool completely, then stack them with parchment paper in between each one. Freeze in a zip-top bag for up to 3 months. Reheat in a toaster or oven when you're ready to enjoy them.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For gluten-free options, substitute the all-purpose flour with a gluten-free flour blend. To make the waffles dairy-free, use almond milk or oat milk in place of regular milk and substitute the butter with coconut oil or a dairy-free butter alternative. For a vegan version, replace the eggs with flax eggs (1 tablespoon ground flaxseed mixed with 2.5 tablespoons water for each egg) and use a plant-based milk and non-dairy butter.

Pairings

These Gingerbread Waffles pair beautifully with a dollop of whipped cream or a drizzle of maple syrup to balance the spices. For a heartier breakfast, consider serving them alongside crispy bacon or sausage links, which complement the sweet and spiced flavors. A warm spiced apple cider or a rich cup of coffee or chai tea would enhance the experience, creating a cozy, festive morning atmosphere.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the Gingerbread Waffles warm on a large platter, stacking them high for a delightful presentation. Dust the top with powdered sugar for a snowy effect, and place small bowls of toppings like maple syrup, whipped cream, and sliced fresh fruits (like bananas or berries) on the side for a make-your-own waffle bar experience. For a special touch, garnish with a sprinkle of cinnamon or nutmeg on the whipped cream and add a few candied ginger pieces for additional flavor and texture.

Gingerbread Waffles

25 min
$8.5
320 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

Dietary Tags:

breakfastbrunchsweetspiced

Description

Deliciously spiced waffles perfect for breakfast or brunch, with a hint of molasses and ginger.

Ingredients

  • all-purpose flour: 1 3/4 cups
  • baking powder: 1 tablespoon
  • baking soda: 1/2 teaspoon
  • ground ginger: 1 teaspoon
  • ground cinnamon: 1 teaspoon
  • ground nutmeg: 1/4 teaspoon
  • salt: 1/2 teaspoon
  • brown sugar: 1/4 cup
  • molasses: 1/2 cup
  • milk: 1 1/2 cups
  • eggs: 2
  • butter, melted: 1/2 cup
